questions.text:
A 6-year-old child was brought to the OPD with complaints of fever, sore throat and difficulty in swallowing. His history is significant for not taking any vaccines for his age. On a clinical examination, the following picture was seen.

What is the mechanism of toxin release by causative organisms for the same?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child has a fever, sore throat, and difficulty in swallowing, with a history of not taking vaccines, and the image shows grey pseudomembrane. These features point towards diphtheria. This is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. ADP ribosylation of EF2 is the mechanism of action of the toxin released by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Diphtheria toxin (DT) is the primary virulence factor responsible for diphtheria.

  • The toxin is synthesised in the precursor form of molecular weight 58,700 kDa, containing a polypeptide made up of 535 amino acids.
  • Toxin has two fragments: A (active) and B (binding) of molecular weights 121,500 and 37,200 kDa, respectively.
  • Fragment B is the binding fragment that binds to the host cell receptors (such as epidermal growth factor) and helps in the entry of fragment A.
  • Fragment A is the active fragment, which causes ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2) -> leads to inhibition of EF-2 -> leads to inhibition of the translation step of protein synthesis.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Inhibit 60S ribosome (Option A): Shiga toxin and Shiga-like toxins cleave the 60S ribosomal subunit, but diphtheria toxin specifically targets EF-2.
  • ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 1 (Option C): No known bacterial exotoxin ADP-ribosylates EF-1.
  • Increase cAMP (Option D): Cholera toxin, pertussis toxin, ETEC heat-labile toxin, and Bacillus anthracis oedema toxin elevate cAMP, unlike diphtheria toxin.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct characteristic of the disease shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows a greyish membrane over the palate, and tonsillar pillars represent faucial diphtheria.

Pathogenicity and Clinical Manifestations:

The pathogenesis of diphtheria is toxin-mediated.

  • Diphtheria is a toxaemia but never a bacteremia.
  • Bacilli are non-invasive, present only at local sites (pharynx), and secrete toxins which spread through the bloodstream to various organs.
  • It is the toxin that is responsible for all types of manifestations, including local (respiratory) and systemic complications (except the skin lesions, which are caused due to the organism, not the toxin).
  • Respiratory Diphtheria: This is the most common form of diphtheria. Tonsil and pharynx (faucial diphtheria) are the most common sites, followed by the nose and larynx. The incubation period is about 3-4 days.
  • Focal diphtheria: Diphtheria toxin elicits an inflammatory response that leads to necrosis of the epithelium and exudate formation.
  • This leads to the formation of mucosal ulcers, lined by a rough,h leathery, greyish white pseudomembrane coat composed of an inner band of fibrin surrounded by neutrophils, RBCs and bacteria.
  • It is named so because it is adherent to the mucosal base and bleeds on removal, in contrast to the true membrane, which can be easily separated.
  • Extension of pseudomembrane: In severe cases, it may extend into the larynx and bronchial airways, which may result in fatal airway obstruction leading to asphyxia. This mandates immediate tracheostomy.
  • Bull-neck appearance: It is characterised by massive tonsillar swelling and neck oedema. Patients present with foul breath, thick speech, and stridor (noisy breathing).

questions.text: You are posted in the dermatology department as an intern, and a 56-year-old female presented to the dermatology OPD with complaints of hyperpigmented lesions in the axilla. On wood's lamp examination, a characteristic coral red fluorescence was seen. What would be the most likely causative organism responsible for a patient's presentation?'
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the above scenario, the hyperpigmented lesion with the wood lamp feature of coral red fluorescence appearance is suggestive of a disease called erythrasma. This is caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum.

Corynebacterium minutissimum

  • It causes a localised infection of skin (the glabrous areas of the body, axilla, groin, inner thighs and between toes), called 'erythrasma'.
  • Erythrasma is a common infection in people living in hot and humid climates.
  • It is a lipophilic Corynebacterium, can be grown readily in media containing 20% fetal calf serum.
  • On Wood's lamp examination, the erythrasma lesion emits a coral red colour.

Explanation of Other Options:

Streptococcus pyogenes (Option A): A gram-positive coccus causing impetigo, cellulitis, and pharyngitis; it does not cause erythrasma and does not fluoresce under Wood's lamp.

Corynebacterium tenuis (Option C): Associated with trichomycosis axillaris, characterised by yellow concretions on axillary and pubic hair shafts, not by coral-red fluorescence.

Micrococcus (Option D): Grows in sweaty areas (palms/soles), producing enzymes that lyse keratin and cause pitted keratolysis; does not present as axillary hyperpigmented lesions or coral-red fluorescence.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old child presents with fever, sore throat and difficulty in breathing. His appearance was as shown in the picture.

Which of the following media will be used for rapid identification of the causative organism of this clinical feature?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario, the patient with fever, sore throat and difficulty in breathing, along with bullneck (image shows), which is because of severe submandibular oedema, represents diphtheria. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Rapid identification of C. diphtheriae

  • Loffler's serum slope (6-8 hours). Löffler's serum slope is enriched with serum and peptone, promoting luxuriant growth of Corynebacterium diphtheriae and rapid development of metachromatic (volutin) granules within 6-8 hours, allowing early presumptive diagnosis.
  • Timely identification on this medium is critical for prompt antitoxin therapy.

Best media for isolation in carriers/contacts/convalescent: PTA (potassium tellurite agar). It is a selective medium.

Examples of selective medium

  • Macleod'medium
  • Downie's medium
  • Hoyle's medium
  • Tinsdale-medium (cysteine tellurite agar)

Laboratory Diagnosis - Corynebacterium diphtheriae

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of fever, muscle aches, and a mild headache. She recently consumed a sandwich containing deli meats. On examination, she is febrile (38.5°C) and has mild neck stiffness. Blood cultures are obtained and grow gram-positive rods that are catalase-positive, motile at 25°C, and tumbling. The organism is non-spore-forming. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The key characteristics in this case-gram-positive rods, catalase-positive, motile at 25°C, and tumbling motility-are highly suggestive of Listeria monocytogenes.

  • Listeria monocytogenesis a gram-positive, catalase-positive rod.
  • It is motile at 25°Cbut is nonmotile at 37°C.
  • This is because peritrichous flagella are produced optimally at 20-30°C but not at 37°C, a temperature typically found in cooler environments like refrigerators, which helps it survive in contaminated foods.
  • It exhibits a characteristic tumbling motilityat lower temperatures.
  • Non-spore-forming:Unlike some other gram-positive rods, Listeria does not form spores.
  • Consumption of deli meatsis a common risk factor for Listeria infection, which can cause symptoms like fever, muscle aches, and gastrointestinal symptoms, and can lead to more severe complications like meningitis, particularly in the elderly, pregnant women, and immunocompromised individuals.

Explanation of other options:

Clostridium botulinum (Option A): Although it is a gram-positive rod, Clostridium botulinum causes botulism, which typically presents with flaccid paralysis and descending muscle weakness, not fever and neck stiffness. Clostridium botulinum is also spore-forming.

Corynebacterium diphtheriae (Option C): It is a gram-positive rod that causes diphtheria, which presents with pharyngitis, a pseudomembrane, and a bull neck but not the constellation of symptoms described in this patient.

Bacillus anthracis (Option D): B.anthracis is also a gram-positive rod, but it is typically associated with cutaneous, inhalation, or gastrointestinal anthrax, and it forms spores. The clinical presentation here is more consistent with Listeria monocytogenes than Bacillus anthracis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old non-immunised boy came to the Pediatric OPD with complaints of fever, sore throat for 5 days and noisy breathing, thick speech and foul breath for 3 days. On clinical examination, his neck had a bull neck appearance, and a greyish membrane was found, as shown in the figure. What should be the dose of Diphtheria Antitoxin given to this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Severe respiratory diphtheria with airway compromise and extensive pseudomembrane formation requires a high dose of antitoxin (80,000-120,000 U) to neutralise circulating toxin quickly.
  • Diphtheria antitoxin must be given intravenously after a skin sensitivity test and administered before antibiotic therapy to prevent further toxin release.
  • Timely high-dose administration reduces mortality and prevents systemic complications such as myocarditis and neuropathy.

Treatment: Corynebacterium diphtheriae

Antidiphtheritic serum (ADS/antitoxin)

  • Passive immunisation with horse-derived antidiphtheritic serum is the treatment of choice, as it neutralises the circulating toxin.
  • A small trial dose must be given first to check for hypersensitivity.
  • Administer intramuscularly (IM) or intravenously (IV) at the following doses based on clinical severity:
    • Mild, early pharyngeal cases: 20,000-40,000 units
    • Moderately severe cases: 40,000-60,000 units
    • Severe, extensive or late cases (> 3 days): 80,000-100,000 units

Antibiotics

  • Penicillin or erythromycin is the drug of choice.
  • Antibiotics do not neutralise the toxin already absorbed, but are useful to:
    • Kill bacilli and prevent further toxin production (especially if given within 6 h of infection)
    • Treat cutaneous diphtheria
    • Eradicate carriage (erythromycin is preferred)

questions.text: Which of the following Corynebacterium species causes endocarditis in bone marrow transplant patients, and to which drug is it sensitive?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Corynebacterium jeikeium is a lipophilic, multidrug-resistant skin commensal in hospitalised, immunocompromised patients (e.g., bone marrow transplant recipients) that can cause bacteremia and endocarditis.
  • This organism is resistant to most β-lactams and aminoglycosides but remains uniformly susceptible to vancomycin, making it the treatment of choice.
  • Prompt recognition and vancomycin therapy are critical to clear C. jeikeium endocarditis and prevent relapse in vulnerable hosts.
  • C. jeikeium is intrinsically resistant to cephalosporins, including ceftriaxone. (Option A ruled out)
  • C.urealyticum: It is a skin commensal, rarely causes urinary tract infection (pyelonephritis) and alkaline encrusted cystitis (struvite stones in alkaline urine) in immunocompromised and renal transplant patients, not endocarditis, and is resistant to many cephalosporins. (Options C & D ruled out)

questions.text: An elderly female patient with thyroid carcinoma metastasised to the lungs became seriously ill following the initiation of chemotherapy. The patient was admitted with symptoms of generalised convulsion and an altered level of consciousness and was treated empirically with meropenem, amikacin and linezolid injection. Cultures of blood and cerebrospinal fluid revealed Listeria monocytogenes on day 5 post-admission. Along with immune suppression, which of the following is a major risk factor for this infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Proton pump inhibitors reduce gastric acidity, impairing the stomach's barrier to ingested pathogens and allowing Listeria monocytogenes to survive and translocate across the gut wall.

Listeriosis

  • Listeriosis is caused by Listeria monocytogenes, which is a food-borne pathogen that can cause serious infections, particularly in neonates, pregnant women and elderly people. It is also a ubiquitous saprophyte and known to cause epizootic disease in birds and animals.
  • Listeriosis is common among extremes of age (neonates and the elderly).
  • Use of proton pump inhibitors increases the risk by reducing the gastric acid-mediated killing of Listeria.
  • Other risk factors: Pregnant women and immunocompromised individuals are at higher risk.
  • Due to its ability to survive refrigeration (4°C), it is commonly found in stored foods, especially aged soft cheeses, packaged meats, milk and cold salads.

Explanation of Other Options:

Beta-lactams (Option A): These antibiotics do not predispose to listeriosis; they are, in fact, active against L. monocytogenes.

ACE inhibitors (Option C): Alter blood pressure but have no known effect on gastric acidity or listerial invasion.

COX-2 inhibitors (Option D): Anti-inflammatory agents without documented impact on gastric pH or listeriosis susceptibility.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a step in the Pathogenesis of listeriosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Listeria spreads directly to adjacent cells via membrane protrusions ("listeriopods"), completing cell-to-cell spread without increasing cAMP.

Pathogenesis of listeriosis:

  • Intracellular survival: After entry into the intestinal epithelium, it survives inside the host cell, mainly due to the lysis of the phagosome by forming pores (mediated by listeriolysin O) (Option B ruled out)
  • Then it causes host cell actin polymerisation, which helps the bacterium to reach near the cell membrane. (Option C ruled out)
  • Finally, it migrates to the adjacent epithelial cells/macrophages by direct cell-to-cell spread, mediated by listeriopods. (Option D ruled out).
  • cAMP elevation is characteristic of toxins like cholera toxin and pertussis toxin, not of Listeria infection.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:
a) Early-onset neonatal listeriosis is acquired from the environment.
b) Late-onset neonatal listeriosis is the most common form of neonatal meningitis.
c) Granulomatosis infantiseptica is a feature of early-onset neonatal listeriosis.
d) Listeria can't cross the placental barrier
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Listeria monocytogenes, the bacterium responsible for listeriosis, can cross the placenta and infect a developing fetus. This is a significant concern during pregnancy because listeriosis can cause serious complications, including miscarriage, stillbirth, premature birth, or infection in the newborn.

Neonatal listeriosis:

Two clinical presentations are recognised: early-onset and late-onset neonatal disease.

Differences between Early- and Late-Onset Neonatal Listeriosis

questions.text: A 54-year-old male, two months after renal transplantation, presented with intermittent fevers, headaches, and loose stools. Before the presentation, he had low-level cytomegalovirus (CMV) viremia for two straight weeks. Given his immunosuppression, diarrhoea, and low-level CMV viremia, he was presumed to have cytomegalovirus and/or C. difficile colitis and treated empirically for both on hospital day one. However, he developed neck pain/stiffness, diaphoresis, and worsening fevers on hospital day three. Blood cultures grow Listeria monocytogenes. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the above clinical scenario, the elderly, immunocompromised patient with features of fever and neck rigidity, along with Listeria growth on blood cultures, is suggestive of meningitis caused by Listeria monocytogenes as a part of invasive listeriosis. The drug of choice for meningitis caused by Listeria is ampicillin.

Listeria in Adults:

  • It produces manifestations such as bacteremia and meningitis in elderly individuals (>60 years).
  • Common risk factors are immunosuppression (steroid therapy, HIV, diabetes, malignancy).
  • Listeria can cause meningitis in kidney transplanted patients 1 month after the transplantation.
  • It also causes gastroenteritis following consumption of contaminated milk, meat and salads.

Treatment:

  • Meningitis: Ampicillin is the drug of choice, given for 2-3 weeks in combination with Gentamicin for synergistic effect.
  • Cotrimoxazole is given to patients with penicillin allergy. In febrile gastroenteritis, Amoxicillin is recommended in immunocompromised, elderly or pregnant patients.
  • Antibiotics to be avoided: Cephalosporins, chloramphenicol are not active in vivo; vancomycin, linezolid, macrolides and tetracyclines are not recommended.
  • Cephalosporins (Ceftriaxone) are commonly used for Neisseria meningitidis and Streptococcus pneumoniae but are not effective against Listeria.

questions.text: The most common species causing the following clinical picture in men is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Actinomyces are soil saprophytes and commensals of the oral cavity.
  • In humans, they cause actinomycosis.
  • A.israelii is the most common species infecting men.
  • Actinomycosis is a chronic suppurative and granulomatous infection characterised by multiple abscesses with formation of sinuses, discharge containing granules and at a later stage, fibrosis and tissue destruction.
  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis is more common in men, often associated with poor oral hygiene or dental procedures, and requires prolonged high-dose penicillin therapy to penetrate fibrotic tissue and fully eradicate infection.

Explanation of Other Options:

Actinomyces naeslundii (Option B): Part of normal oral flora and rarely causes invasive actinomycosis; primarily implicated in dental plaque formation.

Actinomyces odontolyticus (Option C): Also an oral commensal, occasionally identified in actinomycotic lesions but far less common than A. israelii.

Both B and C (Option D): Neither species predominates in human cervicofacial actinomycosis, making this choice incorrect.

choices.text: The infection is mostly endogenous and may result from trauma, e.g. dental extraction.
Name refers to the ray-like appearance of the organism in the granules.
A lumpy jaw is the most common manifestation of actinomycetes.

questions.text: All of the following are true for actinomycetes except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Actinomyces species are non-acid-fast, strict anaerobes.
  • Their infections arise endogenously after mucosal disruption and are not associated with acid-fastness or aerobic growth.
  • The name refers to the ray-like appearance of the organism in the granules (Actinomyces, meaning ray fungus).
  • Mode of infection: As Actinomyces are commensals of the oral cavity, the infection is mostly endogenous and may result from trauma, e.g. dental extraction.
  • Oral-cervicofacial actinomycosis: This is the most common form, usually presenting as a painless, slow-growing, hard mass with cutaneous fistulas, a condition commonly known as lumpy jaw.
  • Sulfur granules are hard and not emulsifiable, consist of branching filamentous bacilli and are surrounded by clubs (sun-ray appearance).

Branched filamentous gram-positive rods, Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon 

Differences between Actinomyces and Nocardia

questions.text: Periodontal disease form of actinomycosis, is caused mainly by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Actinomyces naeslundii and odontolyticus are lipophilic oral commensals that thrive in gingival crevices, where they contribute to dental plaque, caries, and chronic periodontal infections.
  • These species produce biofilm and proteolytic enzymes that degrade periodontal tissues, distinguishing them from A. israelii, which is more commonly associated with cervicofacial "lumpy jaw."
  • Effective management of periodontal actinomycosis targets these organisms with prolonged penicillin therapy and improved oral hygiene to disrupt biofilms.
  • Thoracic actinomycosis may present as cavitary lesions and pleural effusion.
  • Abdominal form: It occurs due to the spillage of intestinal flora secondary to bowel surgery or other conditions of the bowel, such as appendicitis.
  • Pelvic form: It occurs following intrauterine contraceptive device insertion.
  • Brain abscesses.
  • Bone destruction and soft tissue infections.
  • Disseminated form: It may occur due to hematogenous spread.
  • Lungs and liver are the common sites where multiple nodules are formed.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presented to the Dermatology outpatient department (OPD) of a tertiary care hospital in Bihar with a complaint of a large, hard lesion over the left side of the back and another in the left axilla, which were painful, and the one over the back had multiple openings discharging pus. On inspection, the patient had a large plaque-like lesion about 12 cm x 8 cm over the left side of the back. The overlying skin was scarred in places with papules and nodules. Multiple discharging sinuses draining sero-sanguinous fluid were scattered all over the lesion.

Which of the following pictures would be seen on Brown-Brenn modification staining?
A)
B)
C)
D)
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above clinical vignette with noted clinical features, such as multiple lesions with discharging sinuses, is likely to be Actinomycetes.

  • Gram-staining (Brown-Brenn modification): Actinomycetes show a central mass of gram-positive, branching, filamentous bacilli, radiating peripherally with hyaline, club-shaped ends.

Explanation of other options:

Histopathological staining, such as hematoxylin and eosin and Gomori's stained tissue sections of actinomycetes, may reveal granules composed of eosinophilic clubs surrounding basophilic filaments and inflammatory cells such as neutrophils and foamy macrophages (sun-ray appearance)

  • Acid-fast filamentous branching bacilli of Nocardia (modified acid-fast stain).
  • Medusa head colonies of Bacillus anthracis on nutrient agar (10x magnification)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true?
a) Nocardia infection occurs endogenously
b) Nocardia have soft and lobulated granules.
c) Sun-ray appearance of granules is shown by both actinomycetes and Nocardia.
d) Actinomycetes show a fluffy ball at the bottom of the liquid medium.
e) Cotrimoxazole is the treatment for Nocardia.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Nocardia species produce soft, lobulated granules in tissue (b) and are treated effectively with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (e).
  • In liquid culture, Actinomyces form a dense, "fluffy ball" at the bottom, reflecting their filamentous, branching growth (d).

Differences between Actinomyces and Nocardia

questions.text: A patient presented with the following picture and complaint of severe pain, but no pus. Identify the causative organism:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae is a gram-positive bacillus that causes erysipeloid, characterised by intensely painful, well-demarcated violaceous plaques on the hands or fingers after handling fish or animal products, classically called "fish handler's disease."
  • Unlike staphylococcal or streptococcal skin infections, it produces no pus or abscess, reflecting its unique tissue tropism and inflammatory response.
  • The most common sites are the fingers (called "seal finger" and "whale finger").
  • The drug of choice is penicillin G. In penicillin-allergic patients, erythromycin or doxycycline is effective.
  • Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae is intrinsically resistant to Vancomycin.

Explanation of Other Options:

Staphylococcus aureus (Option A): Causes pus-forming abscesses and boils; lesions are typically purulent rather than violaceous and non-purulent.

Streptococcus pyogenes (Option B): Responsible for erysipelas with sharply demarcated red plaques and systemic signs, but often with oedema and sometimes bullae, not the violaceous, non-purulent lesion of erysipeloid.

Bacillus anthracis (Option D): Causes painless black eschars ("malignant pustule") with extensive oedema but minimal pain and is spore-forming, unlike the painful violaceous plaque here.

choices.text: Administer diphtheria antitoxin and start antibiotics (penicillin or erythromycin)
Administer the DTaP vaccine (diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis)
Perform a throat culture on close contacts and provide prophylactic antibiotics to all household members

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the clinic with fever, sore throat and swelling in the neck. The child has an incomplete vaccination history. A throat swab is obtained for culture, and Corynebacterium diphtheriae is isolated. The child is diagnosed with diphtheria. Which of the following is the most important next step in the management of this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Diphtheria, caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, is a toxin-mediateddisease that can cause severe respiratory symptoms, such as a pseudomembrane in the throat, myocarditis, and neuropathy.
  • Immediate management of a confirmed case of diphtheria involves:
    • Diphtheria antitoxin to neutralise the toxin. This is a critical treatment as the toxin can cause damage to the heart and nerves.
    • Antibiotics (usually penicillin or erythromycin) are used to eradicate the bacteria and prevent transmission.

Explanation of Other Options:

Administer a tetanus booster vaccine (Option A): Incorrect, because tetanus is caused by Clostridium tetani; the primary concern in this case is neutralising diphtheria toxin and eradicating C. diphtheriae, not tetanus prophylaxis.

Administer the DTaP vaccine (Option C): Incorrect as an acute measure; DTaP is a preventive immunisation that should have been administered earlier in childhood. The child requires immediate diphtheria antitoxin and antibiotics rather than vaccination during active disease.

Perform a throat culture on close contacts and provide prophylactic antibiotics (Option D): While important for outbreak control, this is secondary. The most urgent step is administering antitoxin and initiating antibiotics for the patient; contact testing and prophylaxis should follow once the child is stabilised.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) presents with a 3-week history of fever, productive cough, and weight loss. He also complains of pleuritic chest pain. Chest X-ray reveals a left-sided pleural effusion. Gram stain of sputum reveals branching, beaded, Gram-positive filaments, and cultures show growth of a partially acid-fast organism. Which of the following is the most likely organism causing this patient's infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient's presentation-fever, cough, weight loss, pleuritic chest pain, and pleural effusion-along with the Gram stain findings of branching, beaded, Gram-positive filaments, is highly suggestive of an infection caused by Nocardia asteroides, a species of the Nocardia genus.

Key features that point to Nocardia:

  • Gram-positive, branching filaments: Nocardia species typically appear as branching, beaded Gram-positive filaments on Gram stain.
  • Partially acid-fast: One of the hallmark features of Nocardia species is their partial acid-fastness, meaning they retain some of the carbol fuchsin stain after exposure to acid-alcohol. This distinguishes Nocardia from many other Gram-positive bacteria.
  • Pulmonary and pleural involvement: Nocardia commonly causes lung infections in immunocompromised individuals (such as those with HIV), and can present with cavitary lesions.

Explanation of Other Options:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Option A): Although M. tuberculosis is acid-fast and can cause chronic pulmonary symptoms, it does not appear as branching, beaded Gram-positive filaments on Gram stain, nor does it grow as a partially acid-fast filamentous organism.

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option B): S. pneumoniae is a Gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococcus, not a filamentous bacterium, and does not exhibit partial acid-fastness or branching morphology.

Corynebacterium diphtheriae (Option D): C. diphtheriae is a non-acid-fast, club-shaped (Chinese-letter) bacillus; it neither branches into filaments nor retains carbol fuchsin in a partially acid-fast stain.

questions.text: Identify the given image:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Elek's gel precipitation is the conventional method to detect diphtheria toxin in vitro.
  • A modified test (recommended by WHO's Diphtheria Reference Unit) is as follows: A filter paper disc impregnated with diphtheria antitoxin (10 IU/mL) is placed on a horse serum agar plate.
  • At least 10 colonies are spot-inoculated 7-9 mm away from the disc and incubated for 48 hours.
  • The antitoxin diffuses out of the disc and forms precipitin bands between the disc and the bacterial growth at the point where it meets the diphtheria toxin (diffusing out of the organisms).

Explanation of other Options:

Nagler's reaction (Option A): The test is used primarily to detect the production of lecithinase by Clostridium perfringens, which is a key virulence factor responsible for tissue necrosis in conditions such as gas gangrene.

Principle:

  • The test involves the use of egg yolk agar(which contains lecithin).
  • When the bacteria produce lecithinase, the enzyme hydrolyses lecithin, causing a clear zone around the bacterial growth due to the breakdown of the lecithin in the agar.

In Nagler's reaction:

  • The control platecontains egg yolk without antitoxin.
  • The test platecontains egg yolk with a specific antitoxin that neutralises lecithinase production.
  • A clear zonearound the bacterial growth in the test plate indicates that perfringens has produced lecithinase.

Satelitism Test (Option C): Haemophilus influenzae colonies show satellitism when grown near S. aureus. This demonstrates the dependence of H. influenzae on the V factor, which is available in high concentrations near staphylococcal growth. Another differentiating test is growth around discs incorporated with X, V and XV factors. This helps in differentiating the species of Haemophilus.

CAMP Test (Option D): CAMP positive: CAMP factor (named after the discoverers: Christie, Atkins-Munch-Petersen) is a phospholipase produced by GBS that causes synergistic hemolysis with beta hemolysin produced by S. aureus. When GBS is streaked on a blood agar plate perpendicular to S. aureus, an enhanced arrowhead-shaped hemolysis is produced at their junction, pointing towards the GBS streak line.
